content.webTitle: Jürgen Klopp urges patience after Liverpool’s young guns shine in Cup

fields.headline: Jürgen Klopp urges patience after Liverpool’s young guns shine in Cup
fields.bodyText: Jürgen Klopp said Liverpool’s young talents “have a lot to learn” and need time to fulfil their potential after Exeter City were soundly beaten in the FA Cup third-round replay at Anfield. The 18-year-old Sheyi Ojo became the youngest goalscorer in Liverpool’s FA Cup history and João Carlos Teixeira was also on the scoresheet in the 3-0 victory as Klopp’s makeshift side secured a fourth-round tie at home to West Ham United. Joe Allen opened the scoring and Jon Flanagan ended his 20-month injury nightmare with a second-half substitute’s appearance. The Liverpool manager was fulsome in his praise of the club’s young players, with the midfielders Kevin Stewart and Cameron Brannagan also impressing, but insisted patience was required before they could be considered for the Premier League. “Ojo is very young, everyone can see he has big skills but there are also a lot of things he has to work on,” Klopp said. “He made a goal that wasn’t too bad. He came on in the last game and was important in the draw. He’s on a good way but it is a long way to go for all the boys. They showed what they are able to do and showed what they still have to learn. Now it is about giving the lads time to develop, not protecting them. “It was a really enjoyable night for football and the lads enjoyed it, you could see that. They worked hard, created chances, scored wonderful goals and made mistakes but worked hard to correct those mistakes. There are a lot of things to learn. The target at the end of the road is Liverpool FC in the Premier League and for this you have to be ready in all parts of development.” Paul Tisdale, the Exeter manager, said he was both proud of the League Two side’s run in the FA Cup – worth £500,000 to the club from the third round alone – but frustrated that his team “took too long to get going. But I shouldn’t be too downbeat tonight.” Flanagan’s first appearance since May 2014 prompted a tweet from Brazil’s World Cup winning captain Cafu, to whom the Liverpool right back was compared prior to his knee problems. “I have a thousand tweets! I guess it’s the return of a friend to the field!!! @LFC” wrote the Brazilian on Twitter. Klopp said: “That was an emotional moment. Nobody deserved it more than Flanno. He has been injured a long time and injured since I came here but he has never been in a bad mood. He’s a really strong lad. We have to take it day-by-day with him.”
